Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: IUSE: EHR: Engaged Student Learning Exploration and Design Tier: Engaging and Enabling Learners to Reason Logically about Code

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The significance of the project is that it will enhance the logical reasoning ability of students, and thus improve the quality of the software they develop after graduation. To make this possible, the project will employ an integrated system of engaging interactive reasoning guides to help overcome individual and collective learning obstacles. These guides will facilitate incremental learning for students and incremental adoption for educators. The automation inherent in the guides will make them an ideal vehicle for impacting learning in personalized and online settings and for reaching a diverse audience.

The project goals include enabling students to reason correctly about code compositions on all valid inputs, pinpointing fine-grain learning obstacles using a logical reasoning approach aided by an automated verification engine, and tailoring the tutoring necessary to help students overcome those obstacles. The scope includes common code idioms from the introductory programming repertoire and more advanced component-based software engineering concepts such as contracts. The underlying verification engine makes it possible for the interactive guides to offer a class of learner activities and directed logical feedback not possible with standard IDEs (Interactive Development Environments) such as Eclipse. Research and evaluation will focus on how well the guides engage students and how learning is improved.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Because software systems, both critical and non-critical, touch our lives daily, it is critical that our future software developers have this ability to write software so that it behaves as it was intended. This project focused on identifying specific learning obstacles that students face when trying to reason symbolically about software. The understanding of at least some of these obstacles was then used to help students learn how to write higher quality software.

Learning to write software can be difficult for many students. Some students are successful, while others struggle to understand how to combine software instructions to form larger components and programs. Often these struggles stem from obstacles encountered in logical (or symbolic) reasoning about the code. The intellectual merit of this project lies with identifying what are the specific reasoning obstacles that students face and subsequently how to utilize this understanding to help them overcome those obstacles. In achieving this goal, the project utilized an online learning environment designed to provide exercises and guide students through those exercises. Students were asked by the environment to express the logical intent of various code fragments. By observing and analyzing students' successes and failures, specific reasoning obstacles were identified. Equally important, the environment presented follow-up exercises based on the specific obstacles encountered by a student. In many cases, these follow-up exercises helped a struggling student eventually succeed with the exercises.

To ensure a broad impact, the learning environment and associated teaching materials were piloted both at Clemson University and Florida Atlantic University. Experimentation at universities with significant differences in student demographics created opportunities for understanding how learning obstacles vary from one student group to another. This understanding is the foundation for developing teaching strategies that benefit all student groups. Results of this project have been disseminated to research and education communities through publications and presentations. The curriculum materials and online learning environment are publicly available and in active use at multiple institutions.
